6. In this case, we're adding the condition "the wuggy is out of zloat" to the original antecedent.

7. The consequent (the "then" part) remains unchanged in both statements.

8. Therefore, if the original statement is true, the new statement with the strengthened antecedent must also be true, regardless of whether "the wuggy is out of zloat" or not.

9. The additional condition doesn't affect the logical relationship between "the klank is hooped" and "the wuggy will zink."
